column4: so I don't know what path it's using for md5. It's something to do with how it accesses media mounts I guess.
It puts %20 in the spaces in the pathname.
So, like, if your CD is /media/Metallica is cool/Metallicachick.png it will md5 file:///media/Metallica%20is%20cool/Metallicachick.png and store the hash of this path in ~/.thumbnails/normal
I have a feeling nobody else will ever have this question.
I think it runs it through an escaping function call.
It would be helpful to know which one it is.

I'm not sure what nautilus thumbnails is, but typically, for a launcher, %u will result in a url (which gui applications typically groks), and %f will result in a filename (that command-line tools can grok)
I don't know if that's used for your case though
At any rate, the best solution is to find a way to send your command a filename instead of an url in the first place. Converting an url back into a filename is very cumbersome
it seems that when you create a shortcut using nautilus it stores a uri.
